text: I guess the report was false. Seems pretty calm here. That's fine by me. One night off from coming to the rescue? Perfect. Maybe we can get a little rest and relaxation while we're here...

speaker: Silas
text: Hey! Listen up. trouble's brewing. The town watch chased off some bandits. But they returned with friends. And more are coming. This town's about to be sacked.

speaker: Laslow
text: What? Then we've got to get in there and help!

speaker: Silas
text: Yes, let's. The town watch is in way over their heads. Though it's said they have a skilled mercenary leading them. She's also got the happiest band of me I've ever seen—they're all smiles!

speaker: Laslow
text: Hmm? I wonder who she is? All smiles, you say? Uh-oh. It can't be...Soleil?

speaker: Silas
text: Yes, that's her name. So you know this girl? I can't believe she'd dare come to such a dread place as this.

speaker: Laslow
text: You don't know my daughter. She doesn’t' get the chills easily.

speaker: Silas
text: What?! Soleil is your daughter? But isn't your child off in her Deeprealm?

speaker: Laslow
text: Well, she should be. But Soleil is her own woman—like a force of nature. She's gathered a band of do-gooders around her. She's just like that. But Soleil and her men shouldn't be here. These bandits mean business.

speaker: Silas
text: Wait, Laslow! Are you sure that this Soleil is your daughter? We can't just run in—it could be some sort of trap!

speaker: Soleil
text: Father?! What brings you here?

speaker: Laslow
text: You all right, Soleil?

speaker: Soleil
text: Always! I am your daughter, after all. Nothing ever gets to me! Not even these bandits! Well, I mean... Maybe I was worried. But only a... Only a...

speaker: Laslow
text: Hmm? Daughter?

speaker: Soleil
text: OK. I'll admit it. This is bad. And I can't bring myself to tell my men.

speaker: Laslow
text: Soleil, I know I always said to keep on smiling. But sometimes it's fine to drop it if it feels like an act. Still, you'll have to forgive me if I smile, looking at you here. You've grown into such a hero! Let me share one of my secrets. If battle is turning against me... And I can't smile? I laugh. A lot. It really confuses the enemy. Then I get the upper hand, and I'm smiling again before I know it!

speaker: Soleil
text: Whoa. That's brilliant.

speaker: Laslow
text: See? There's that smile again. An honest smile. Nothing lovelier. Ready to smile? Laugh? Whatever it takes out there to win?

speaker: Soleil
text: Woo-hoo! Yeah!

speaker: Zhara
text: You don't know me. I don't know you. But before I was a bandit...? I was a swordsman. The best! Come on—I'll test my blade on you.

speaker: Laslow
text: Soleil, you were amazing.

speaker: Soleil
text: Wahooo! Thanks, Father. And thanks to all your friends. I'm so happy that you came.

speaker: Laslow
text: I'm happy that you're alive. This was no piece of cake.

speaker: Silas
text: Um, if I may? We could use someone like her—fighting with a smile on her face. We're always on such a grim march. She'd put some pep in our step.

speaker: Laslow
text: Huh? Aren't I smiley enough?

speaker: Soleil
text: Yaaay! I'd love to come! You have to let me, Father. You HAVE to!

speaker: Laslow
text: Well, um...

speaker: Silas
text: Once more, Laslow? I couldn't hear you through your frown.

speaker: Laslow
text: Um...all right. I could use some extra support on the smiley front.

speaker: Silas
text: Hmmm? Who's this?

speaker: Girl
text: Thank you, Soleil! Our town would be a pile of rocks if you hadn't helped! Here, something to remember us by!

speaker: Soleil
text: Oh! My goodness...

speaker: Girl
text: Um, what's with the blushing? You're pink as a rose, Soleil.

speaker: Soleil
text: Wow. Cute! Um...hi! Again. Did I say hi? Sorry. Blanked out there. You're just too pretty for words. But I guess those are words. About you being pretty.

speaker: Girl
text: Hmm, I am?

speaker: Soleil
text: Let's go stargazing. Shall we? Do you want to? Just the two of us?

speaker: Girl
text: Yes! I'd love to!

speaker: Soleil
text: Whoa. Really? You and me, beneath the stars? I can't wait!

speaker: Silas
text: Hmm, Laslow, did your daughter just ask that girl out to gaze at the stars?

speaker: Laslow
text: Why, yes! She's got good taste. In women as well as men—got a problem with that?

speaker: Silas
text: No, of course not.

speaker: Soleil
text: Wahooo! She said yes, Father! See, I always told you—be honest with women. It's not a game. Just wear your heart on your sleeve. On BOTH your sleeves!

speaker: Laslow
text: Soleil...I guess I can look forward to more of these dating tips, eh?

speaker: Soleil
text: I don't imagine we'll have much time for these little daughter-father chats. But you can always rely on me!

speaker: Laslow
text: It's true. We're at war. But I'll always have time for you, Soleil.

speaker: Silas
text: What a breath of fresh air. How'd someone like YOU end up with a great daughter?

speaker: Laslow
text: What do you mean, ME? But, yes. I suppose I am fortunate to have such a delight as Soleil in my life!

speaker: Saizo
text: Hey, Azama, you look terrible. Like you've seen a ghost.

speaker: Azama
text: No, nothing that awful. It's just that my daughter's village is under attack.

speaker: Saizo
text: What? That's FAR worse. We have to get there and rescue her.

speaker: Azama
text: Let's see... I guess it is worse, though everyone has to die sometime.

speaker: Saizo
text: What?! We're talking about your daughter here! Let's get to saving her, man!

speaker: Azama
text: Impatient, aren't you? Then let's go, if you're in such a hurry.

speaker: Saizo
text: My god! The village in this Deeprealm is completely overrun with our enemies! This is where Mitama lives, right? Then where IS your daughter?

speaker: Azama
text: This is not good... I don't see her anywhere... Oh! Ah! I'm wrong. There's an air of calm here. She must be fine.

speaker: Saizo
text: Hmm. Somehow I seriously doubt that. Look at this place, you fool.

speaker: Azama
text: Um, well...she's probably fine. I put her in a perfectly sound house.

speaker: Azama
text: See? That place is still standing. It hasn't taken any damage.

speaker: Saizo
text: ... We're going in to check on her safety, you damned fool.

speaker: Azama
text: Mitama? Knock knock! It's your father. Are you home?

speaker: Mitama
text: Wh-who?

speaker: Azama
text: Oh, you are home. Could you come to the door, please? It's only fair that you join us outside. Or let us all in. Either way.

speaker: Mitama
text: Who? What now? Off with you. I'm enjoying a lovely snooze...

speaker: Azama
text: Oh, my! Did she fall back asleep?

speaker: Azama
text: Mitama? Please open up. My knuckles are getting sore from knocking.

speaker: Mitama
text: Who's there? Didn't I say to go away? I don't want any! Haven't you a higher calling than to trouble my door? Mayhaps you should place yourself in a prostrate position, then perish?

speaker: Azama
text: How strange. Explain yourself, Mitama.

speaker: Mitama
text: How can I make it any clearer? Lay down and die!

speaker: Azama
text: Ah! That most certainly is you, Daughter. I'd know that sharp tongue anywhere. It's your father, Mitama. Open up, pretty please. I'm getting rude stares. People don't understand why you won't let me in. Me? I could stand here all day and banter with you. Great fun. Still, I'd rather not knock a third time. Mitama...?

speaker: Mitama
text: Oh, is that you, Father? What brings you here? Did you bring all these hooligans who've been making so much noise?

speaker: Azama
text: Blissfully unaware, as always. Nice to see you too, Daughter.

speaker: Mitama
text: Yes, well, I've been asleep. Or trying to. But all this noise out here!

speaker: Azama
text: Oh my. What a dreamer! You might have slept through your house being razed. Good thing I had the common sense to get here as fast I could.

speaker: Mitama
text: I understand. You're saving me. That's worth waking up for. Or at least it's haiku worthy. My father has come. / But my feather bed is warm. / So I choose to snooze. Good night, Father.

speaker: Azama
text: Good night, my left foot! Have you taken a look around? It's not night! And it's not good - not with your village being under attack! Outside, now. If I have to battle, you have to battle.

speaker: Mitama
text: What? Why?

speaker: Azama
text: Dear Daughter, do I really need to explain? You're brighter than most. It's time that your laziness is forged into the will to fight. Besides, I need you to heal me up if I scuff my knee.

speaker: Mitama
text: You woke me for this? I guess this too is haiku worthy. My best friends are snores. / But who has come to my door? / The master of chores. Ugh, I guess I'll help. Now where did I put that rod? Oh, yes. There.

speaker: Azama
text: Hmm... Oh, dear, I've never seen a filthier apparatus. What HAVE you been stirring with this, Daughter? It'll have to do. Ready to help?

speaker: Mitama
text: OK, I guess. Just a moment... Beseeches he me? / I am the Maiden of Zs. / At the least say please.

speaker: Mitama
text: Oh. Is someone injured?

speaker: Azama
text: Whoa, just look at that. What initiative! Tending to the wounded without even being nagged? Remarkable!

speaker: Mitama
text: Whew. Healing people is exhausting.

speaker: Azama
text: Well done, Mitama.

speaker: Mitama
text: Yes, it was, wasn't it? Now, good night.

speaker: Azama
text: Oh? Where do you think you're going?

speaker: Mitama
text: Very funny, Father. Inside to bed, of course. Since all of those obnoxious visitors are gone, I can get back to sleep.

speaker: Azama
text: Is it funny, how you think you're just going to hit the hay after being so useful! No, dear Daughter. You're going to accompany us.

speaker: Mitama
text: What?!

speaker: Azama
text: All right. Let's go. No complaining. As they say; those that idle away their lives are looking for trouble.

speaker: Midori
text: Hup, two, three, four! Hup, two, three, four! Keep it going, Midori. One after the other. You'll get there! Hup, two— But I do hope I'll be there soon. I wouldn't want to keep Father waiting. He's going to be so happy that I found the rare herb he wanted! Got it tucked nice and safe in my little bag here. Hup, two, three— Aaaagh! Am I there yet? I've marched ALL the way from my Deeprealm to meet him! Hup, two, three—uh, hang on. What's that up ahead?

speaker: Boy
text: Help me! Somebody! Anybody!

speaker: Ruffian
text: Shut up! Now empty your pockets like I told you—or I'll CUT 'em open. And I ain't too careful with my knife, if ya know what I mean.

speaker: Boy
text: Leave me alone!

speaker: Midori
text: Wh-what are you doing?! Pick on someone your own size!

speaker: Ruffian
text: What? Who said that?! Ha! Ain't you a li'l tater.

speaker: Midori
text: Nuh-uh! I'm Midori, the biggest herb gatherer around! Now, do the adult thing and put down tour weapons, you...you... You pocket emptier!

speaker: Ruffian
text: What's that?! Ain't your parents ever teach you to respect your elders? Guess I'll just have to teach you to shut your yap.

speaker: Midori
text: Huh? No!

speaker: Ruffian
text: Gaaah!

speaker: Kaze
text: Midori... I'm here. You're safe.

speaker: Midori
text: Father!

speaker: Ruffian
text: Urr, who—? Never mind. I'm gone. Got better pockets to empty.

speaker: Midori
text: Thanks a bunch, Father! I hope you weren't too worried. I wasn't.

speaker: Kaze
text: Is that so? Then maybe do me a favor next time and be on time. I'll always worry. That's my job. Well now. Have you gotten taller again? You're growing faster than bamboo!

speaker: Midori
text: Oh, yes! But it's time that's going by so fast in the Deeprealms. I'm an adult now—or at least more one than that brute was. Anyway, Father, I found the rare herbs you wanted! See? I've got them right here! Er, hold on. They were right here. I had them just a moment ago!

speaker: Kaze
text: Huh? Did you drop the herbs when that bandit approached you?

speaker: Midori
text: Um...no! I'm sure I didn't drop them!

speaker: Kaze
text: Hmm...then where are they? Let's just retrace your steps. They must have slipped through your fingers.

speaker: Midori
text: No way. I'm sure I didn't misplace them. I was JUST holding the bag! It must have been that man. He took the herbs from me. Wait here, Father! I'll find that guy and get the bag back.

speaker: Kaze
text: No, Midori. Wait!

speaker: Midori
text: Um... Hey, you! Yes, YOU! With the bag! That's mine!

speaker: Candace
text: Eh? Sharp eye, kid. People don't usually see me when I'm tiptoeing around.

speaker: Midori
text: Well, the fact is, I'm not a kid. I'm the biggest herb gatherer around! And you're running around with some pretty bad guys!

speaker: Candace
text: Well, if we're comparing facts, I am NOT with these barbarians. I travel among them. They make for a nice distraction while I do my work. No one even sees me walk amid the whole hairy, smelly horde of them! And who am I, you may ask? She who locates legendary riches! A genius! And explorer! I'm none other than Candace, the notorious treasure hunter!

speaker: Midori
text: Um, what? Does this have something to do with my bag? Explain yourself!

speaker: Candace
text: Leave it to Candace! I have explanations for every occasion! You see, I learned that the rare Dragon Herbs were hereabouts! As I've said, I am a treasure hunter. You had something I treasured. The rest is just math. Ergo, what's yours is now mine.

speaker: Midori
text: Well, the fact is that I found those herbs first. You stole my bag!

speaker: Candace
text: Facts again? Then let me drop another fact on you. You took the herbs from this forest, didn't you? Wouldn't that make YOU a thief?

speaker: Midori
text: Nuh-uh!

speaker: Candace
text: Then I'm not a thief either! I could stand here and complain about you dragging my name through the mud. But Candace is going to take the high road—and just say good-bye. You could try to take back your bag. But I'll warn you. I'm quick as a wink.

speaker: Midori
text: No, wait! I need those herbs for my father!

speaker: Candace
text: Oh? Caught up with Candace, did you? Well done. But I'll warn you. I'm strong as an oak!

speaker: Midori
text: Glad that's over. I wasn't sure we were going to get the herbs back!

speaker: Kaze
text: Don't scare me like that. Running off on me? I was terrified! All of this, just for those herbs? We could have gathered more. They're not worth the risk of losing you. So never do that again!

speaker: Midori
text: But I just— Ugh, you don't understand! Those herbs grow here only once every year! And you don't realize the true value of those herbs anyway. Those herbs can make wishes come true!

speaker: Kaze
text: Huh? I knew they were useful, but they can actually grant wishes?

speaker: Midori
text: Well the fact is...the herbs can help make one specific wish come true. My wish, in fact—to prove my usefulness to you, Father. So I can stay here!

speaker: Kaze
text: Midori, we still could have waited for the herbs to grow back. This was risky.

speaker: Midori
text: Don't you realize?! A year here would be FOREVER in my Deeprealm! And I just can't wait THAT long to prove my usefulness again! I...I...hate it there, away from you!

speaker: Kaze
text: I'm sorry that I've put you through all of this, Midori. It was only for your safety. But it seems that you're more than old enough to make your own choices. Forgive me for not realizing what you were going through much earlier. Of course, time is more fleeting in the Deeprealms. I planned to visit as often as I could, since days here would be much longer for you. I am dearly sorry for putting you through such loneliness.

speaker: Kaze
text: Here, take my hand, Midori. From now on, we walk together in life. No more Deeprealms for you.

speaker: Midori
text: You're serious, Father?

speaker: Kaze
text: Of course! I'll just go let my comrades know that you'll be joining us.

speaker: Midori
text: Thank you, Father! Now, see? I was right about the power of these herbs! My greatest wish is coming true!

speaker: Kaze
text: Let's go, Midori. We have a lot to catch up about. I want to know everything about your life in your Deeprealm. I've missed out on so much. Tell me about it all—and don't leave out a single day.

speaker: Midori
text: Yes, Father. That will surely keep us busy for at least a few years!

speaker: Kana
text: Ah! What a lovely day! I might just break out in song! And twirl all the day long! Hmm. But Papa/Mama is visiting today, and I haven’t seen him/her in such a long time. I’d better do something special for him/her. Gather some fruit? Fish for fish? Ha, I know! Papa/Mama should have both. So I’d better get going!

speaker: Kana
text: Wh-who are you? Y-you look weird! Get away from me!

speaker: Kana
text: Umm, what do you all want? You’d better not be here to make trouble. My papa/mama will be here soon! They’re not listening. But I can’t just run. They look ready to do evil things!

speaker: Kana
text: Oof!

speaker: Corrin
text: Phew! Here in the nick of time. Are you all right, Kana?

speaker: Kana
text: P-Papa/M-Mama?

speaker: Corrin
text: I’m so sorry, Kana. You’ve been safe here for so long. I never thought anyone would come here to hurt you. Please tell me you’re OK!

speaker: Kana
text: Yeah, Papa/Mama.

speaker: Corrin
text: Thank the gods. Now, off with you. Your papa/mama has everything in hand. YOU! You dare touch my child?! I'll soak these fields with your blood!

speaker: Kana
text: Papa/Mama, there are too many of them!

speaker: Corrin
text: I'll protect you, Kana. But don't worry about me. I told you to run! Now, the rest of you! Prepare to join your comrades in death!

speaker: Corrin
text: They’re tough... But I have to... keep them away from...

speaker: Kana
text: No! You bunch of bullies! Stop hurting Papa/Mama!

speaker: Corrin
text: Kana! How many times do I need to tell you?! Run!

speaker: Kana
text: No! I’m not going to leave, Papa/Mama! Not when I’ve waited so long to see you again! No one’s going to take you from me! I’m staying right—rrgg! Right here by—RRRG! By your—RRAWRGH!

speaker: Corrin
text: Kana?! You're...

speaker: Kana
text: RRAAAAWRG!

speaker: Corrin
text: It can't be. She/He shouldn't have the ability to—

speaker: Kana
text: RRRAWWRRGGRR!

speaker: Corrin
text: No...she/he must have inherited it from me. But for it to awaken here, now? She's/He's out of control. This...this must be her/his first time transforming! She's/He's at risk of losing herself/himself to a mindless rampage in the face of these foes! Friends, join me! We must clear the field of this menace—fast!

speaker: Llewelyn
text: Mwahaha. What have we here, Lloyd?

speaker: Lloyd
text: Hey, bro! I don't know.

speaker: Llewelyn
text: It's plain as the nose on your face. Can't you see it over there?

speaker: Lloyd
text: Huh? See what? Where?

speaker: Llewelyn
text: I dunno, my nearsighted brother. Maybe I mean that dragon yonder?

speaker: Lloyd
text: Who'd name a dragon Yonder?!

speaker: Llewelyn
text: No, you addle-brained baboon. I mean that dragon way OVER yonder.

speaker: Lloyd
text: Why didn't you say so? Dragons are like gods! We should catch it!

speaker: Llewelyn
text: Yes. We'll make it our pet. A god on a leash! But let's proceed sensibly. We must pummel it to the brink of death. But what SHOULD we name it...?

speaker: Lloyd
text: That dragon's mine! I'm going to name it Llizardface!

speaker: Kana
text: Whuh... whuh... What... What happened, Papa/Mama? I dreamed that I turned into a dragon!

speaker: Corrin
text: Yes, well... You did, Kana.

speaker: Kana
text: I did? For real? You look upset, Papa/Mama. I didn’t mean to do it, I only wanted to protect you! But I’m small. And I felt... useless. Then I felt myself get so angry. I heard a roaring in my head... It got louder and louder, until I couldn’t hear myself thinking anymore. I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to turn into a dragon. Am I in trouble now?

speaker: Corrin
text: No! Far from it. You’ve made me the happiest father/mother in the world. I turn into a dragon too.

speaker: Kana
text: What? Papa/Mama, you–?

speaker: Corrin
text: Listen, Kana. I’m sorry that I haven’t visited you enough to explain... But I keep my power in control by using very special stones. You must too. Or else the dragon within may take over. Don’t be scared – you just need a stone. Azura has given me a stone that you can use. Carry this with you always.

speaker: Kana
text: Thank you. It’s such a beautiful stone. I’ll treasure it, Papa/Mama! But now that I can turn into a dragon... can I maybe travel with you?

speaker: Corrin
text: I’m so sorry, Kana. But you’re too young. And my world is too dangerous.

speaker: Kana
text: No, Papa/Mama? I guess I can wait longer, but only if you promise to visit more often.

speaker: Corrin
text: Oh... Of course. I promise. Cross my heart and hope to— Er, I promise—that’s all. And I’ll be sure to bring you a nice gift next time I come.

speaker: Kana
text: Yeah... All right, Papa/Mama.

speaker: Corrin
text: That’s my girl/boy. Be good, Kana, and you keep hanging on to that stone!

speaker: Kana
text: ...Hmpf. No, Papa/Mama. WAIT!

speaker: Corrin
text: Kana, I have to go. A lot of people are depending on your papa/mama.

speaker: Kana
text: I... I know! That’s why I have to go with you! I’m depending on you too... to come back! And I never know if you’ll... if you’ll... If you’ll DIE and never come back! What if I grow old enough to leave here, but by then you’re gone?

speaker: Corrin
text: Kana, I’m only trying to protect you! But if that’s how you feel... If it’s agony for you being here? That’s the last thing I want. Maybe... All right. You’re coming. With your new powers, you might be safer with me. I need to explain all of this to my friends. You need to say good-bye to yours.

speaker: Kana
text: What, I get to come with you? Really?

speaker: Corrin
text: Yes, really. But, Kana, it’s a different world out there. It’s not a game – it’s scary. I’ll look after you. Still, are you sure you’re grown-up enough for this?

speaker: Kana
text: Well... I’m only a little kid. But I’m old enough to be a dragon. And my papa’s/mama's one too.

speaker: Corrin
text: Like father, like daughter/Like mother, like son. I guess there’s a lot we should catch up about.

speaker: Kana
text: Yes! I can’t wait! Papa/Mama, I have to say one more thing before we leave. Rrrghg rawrgghh rrrh! That's dragon for I love you!

speaker: Jakob
text: Excuse me? Hello? Anyone? I’m looking for my son Dwyer! Hmpf. As always, that lazy lout is probably snoring away somewhere. Clearly, his bad attitude has infected this whole village. What a sleepy place. Why do I even bother fetching Dwyer his favorite coffee beans? How did I come to buttle my son, when he should come running to serve me? What’s this? Who’s there? I see you scurrying in the shadows. Get over here! Of all the... My son can’t even have me greeted properly on my arrival?

speaker: Jakob
text: What? How’d you get here? Did you follow me? Speak, villain. Now! Or I’ll cut the answer out of you!

speaker: Jakob
text: Eh? Where’s that fiend going? No! There are more of them, and they’re breaking into Dwyer’s house! SON! THEY’RE COMING FOR YOU!

speaker: Dwyer
text: Who’s that yelling like a maniac outside? As if I don’t have enough trouble. Urrr, is that my father? Of course he’d have to show up in the middle of all this. Well, forget him. I’ve got enough to worry about, keeping us all alive in here. Everyone! Stay close! I’ll heal you up if you get hurt!

speaker: Jakob
text: Was that Dwyer? What’s that damned fool doing?! Hanging back? Letting others do the fighting for him? It’s a disgrace!

speaker: Jakob
text: Dwyer, I’ve found you.

speaker: Dwyer
text: Father! What a surprise. I’d fetch you a glass of my finest whatever. That is, if I wasn’t busy with my other uninvited guests.

speaker: Jakob
text: Of all the... Uninvited?! I’m your father, Dwyer! And just look at the way you’re conducting yourself in your own household! I taught you martial arts! And you’re dillydallying in the background? Healing, not fighting?

speaker: Dwyer
text: Oh, Father, there’s no shame in standing by to help when needed. Isn’t that what a good butler does? Serve, not show up his masters?

speaker: Jakob
text: What was that? Are you slighting my profession?

speaker: Dwyer
text: What? Not in the slightest. But if you expect me to jump into battle... then I think you’ve got the wrong son. I’m a healer, not a fighter.

speaker: Jakob
text: Dwyer, Dwyer... You always did run from a fight. Go on then. Let your father do all the work.

speaker: Dwyer
text: Give me a break. You never did see me for who I was. Perhaps I was a tad idle as a child. But now, I keep people alive.

speaker: Jakob
text: Don’t bother. I’ll keep everyone alive... by defending them with MY life. So, unless my Little Lord Lazybones wishes me to fetch his slippers... No? Or a cup of warm milk? Then stand aside and watch how it’s done, Son.

speaker: Dwyer
text: Hmm. Go on then.

speaker: Dwyer
text: That was pretty good, Father. You and your friends cleaned this place up.

speaker: Jakob
text: And that, my son, is why your remaining servants just left.

speaker: Dwyer
text: Huh? They did?

speaker: Jakob
text: Hmm. Even your caretakers too. I’m not surprised, the way you run this household. It’s a den of a sloth.

speaker: Dwyer
text: Oh no... They really are gone! Now who’s going to help me maintain my high standard for squalor? Who will bring in all the dirt? Or feed hair balls to the dust bunnies? I can't do it ALL by myself!

speaker: Jakob
text: Hmpf...

speaker: Dwyer
text: You’ll just have to take me with you, Father.

speaker: Jakob
text: Ha! We all pull our weight in our group. I’d never vouch for you. You’re going to stew here for the rest of your days in this mess of a place.

speaker: Dwyer
text: Father? You missed one. Oh, never mind. I’ve got it.

speaker: Jakob
text: Dwyer?! What in—

speaker: Dwyer
text: You’ve got a lot of nerve, sneaking up on my father. Well, take this! SLAPPYFACE!

speaker: Dwyer
text: Whew! Who knew? Victory!

speaker: Jakob
text: Oh, well. I stand corrected. You might not be able to handle a weapon. But your slappyface is unparalleled. Have you been... in training?

speaker: Dwyer
text: I guess so. Wait, are you kidding? Because I don’t always laze around here.

speaker: Jakob
text: Well, how irksome. Here I had you pegged for a complete loafer. But if you could fight, even a little, why did you make your servants do it for you?

speaker: Dwyer
text: Hmm? Wasn’t it their job to watch over me? I would never rob them of their work.

speaker: Jakob
text: With that sort of attitude, I’m afraid that you’ll never be good for much. Do you expect me to find you fresh caretakers to abuse?

speaker: Dwyer
text: No. I’m going to turn over a new leaf. I’ll serve your friends!

speaker: Jakob
text: What?!

speaker: Dwyer
text: If you can buttle, I can buttle. I bet I’ll buttle better. Hey, did you bring those coffee beans I wanted? Hand ‘em over. I’ll brew everyone a cup of the best coffee they’ve ever had!

speaker: Jakob
text: But that’s MY job!

speaker: Dwyer
text: What’s the matter? Afraid of a little competition? This should be fun. En garde, Father. I declare this battle of buttling begun!

speaker: Jakob
text: Hmpf. You don’t stand a chance.

speaker: Velouria
text: Oooh, cool. There are so many acorns around here. *sniff* They have such a nice scent too. So earthy, so rich. I should find the very nicest one and give it to Daddy as a present. But maybe if I pick a fresh one from one of those trees... Huh? What's up there? Behind those branches? It looks like some sort of weird portal... *sniff, sniff* What? That scent! I'd recognize it anywhere. Smells like my daddy!

speaker: Keaton
text: We're almost there. Now, where is that darn portal exactly? My daughter, Velouria, is beyond it in her Deeprealm.

speaker: Kaze
text: I'm looking forward to meeting your daughter. You've said she's more like you than her mother—right down to the tail?

speaker: Keaton
text: Yup! Pretty much exactly like me. Except that she prefers her own company. A real lone wolf! She's not used to being around others. You might find her...overwhelming. She really wears her heart on her sleeve. Like, REALLY really.

speaker: Kaze
text: Wait, who's there?! Watch out—trouble approaches!

speaker: Kaze
text: What? It seems we're about to be ambushed.

speaker: Keaton
text: Not the best timing. I hate to keep Velouria waiting. But I'm game for a fight.

speaker: Keaton
text: Hrm? I'm picking up the slightest scent of wolfskin somewhere. To the...west? Yes! On the other side of those mountains! Who could it be...? Oh, no. It's Velouria. But how? I've never shown her where the portal is on her side. It can't be her. But that's definitely her scent coming from the west!

speaker: Velouria
text: Daddy? *sniff, sniff* Is that you?

speaker: Keaton
text: *sniff* Velouria? By all the hair in my ears! What are you doing here?

speaker: Velouria
text: I was hunting for just the right gift for you when I caught your scent! Then I found the portal to your world! I can't believe I found you, my dear, daring, dashing Daddy!

speaker: Keaton
text: I, uh... Those are a lot of Ds. Let's save the tail-wagging until later, Velouria. We're in trouble here.

speaker: Velouria
text: Oh. Are we? How about I lend a hand? Or a paw? I've been perfecting my hunting skills off in my Deeprealm. I'm fiercer than the last time you saw me, Daddy.

speaker: Velouria
text: Aw, the hunt is over already... That was fun. Thanks for arranging such a nice game, Daddy.

speaker: Keaton
text: Um, that wasn't a game, Velouria. I'm not exactly happy to see you here. You could have been hurt.

speaker: Velouria
text: Daddy, I can see your tail wagging. I know you're happy to see me!

speaker: Keaton
text: Whuh? My tail's twitching, that's all. I'm actually very, very, very angry with you, Daughter.  Now, Velouria, I want you to scamper back to your Deeprealm. Off with you. I'm busy. You know the way out.

speaker: Velouria
text: Grrrah!

speaker: Keaton
text: Hrm? Watch your tone, Daughter.

speaker: Velouria
text: No! I mean, yes. I'll watch my tone. But I'm not going back. I'm joining your pack, Daddy.

speaker: Keaton
text: Velouria, this isn't a pack. We're, uh, comrades-in-arms or something. No way. Never. Go, now!

speaker: Velouria
text: Huh, But, Daddy...I'm so confused. Your tail is wagging YES.

speaker: Keaton
text: Whuh? Gaah!

speaker: Velouria
text: Hey, I just remembered. Before I went through the portal, I found this for you. The perfect acorn!

speaker: Keaton
text: Wow! That's the prettiest acorn I've ever laid eyes on. So glossy! It's like a pearl! From a tree! Which reminds me. I have a gift for you too, Daughter. Here...

speaker: Velouria
text: Oh, wow! A bat? It's all shriveled. Its wings are ripped up. Did you chew on it? Daddy, it's perfect. You're wonderful.

speaker: Keaton
text: Er, am I? Sure, why not? I guess I am! But as far as you coming with us...? Oh, all right.

speaker: Velouria
text: Really?! *wag, wag* *sniff, sniff* *wag, sniff, wag*

speaker: Keaton
text: Ha! That tickles, Velouria! All right, you're happy. I get it.

speaker: Velouria
text: I'm sorry. I'm just so glad to be part of your pack at last, Daddy.

speaker: Keaton
text: All right, all right. But it's not my pack, OK? That's not how this group works. *waggity, waggity, waggity* Ha! There goes my tail again. Welcome, Daughter! Welcome, welcome, welcome, welcome, welcome!

speaker: Velouria
text: OK, Daddy. Settle down. Now you're embarrassing me!

speaker: Subaki
text: It's been so long since I was last in this Deeprealm. How peaceful it is. Now then, where is my daughter?

speaker: Caeldori
text: Father, here I am. Welcome back.

speaker: Subaki
text: Caeldori, my dear! You've grown even more beautiful while I've been away.

speaker: Caeldori
text: Goodness. Please, Father. You're embarrassing me.

speaker: Subaki
text: Do I dote too much? Maybe so. You've been well, I hope?

speaker: Caeldori
text: Yes, of course. I've kept up with every aspect of my training and studies. And in my spare time, I've memorized several books about war strategy.

speaker: Subaki
text: Wow! Impressive. Trying to be perfect, just like your father?

speaker: Caeldori
text: I'm aiming for capable. I've never seen real combat yet...

speaker: Subaki
text: Take your time, Daughter. Don't rush yourself. The reason my friends and I are constantly at war is to end war.

speaker: Hoshidan
text: Reporting, sir. Urgent news from the other side. Enemies are attacking a site as we speak—you're needed at once.

speaker: Subaki
text: All right. I'll go at once.

speaker: Caeldori
text: I'm here too! I can fight, Father!

speaker: Subaki
text: You want to join me?

speaker: Caeldori
text: Well, why not? I would learn so much more in actual combat. Besides, don't you need all the help you can get?

speaker: Subaki
text: No, we've got it under control, Caeldori. You're brave to volunteer. I couldn't bear the thought of putting you in harm's way.

speaker: Caeldori
text: But, Father!

speaker: Subaki
text: Caeldori, don't you worry. My friends are excellent at what they do. And I must say that I approach perfection on the battlefield. Wait here. I'll return as soon as the battle's over.

speaker: Caeldori
text: I, um... But...

speaker: Subaki
text: No buts, Caeldori. I'll be back in a jiffy.

speaker: Caeldori
text: Oh, Father... Hmmm.

speaker: Subaki
text: How is this possible? They've swarmed this area? Is there no end to them? The odds seem...against us.

speaker: Caeldori
text: Let me help, Father!

speaker: Subaki
text: Caeldori, you shouldn't be here!

speaker: Caeldori
text: I'm sorry. I don't mean to disobey you. But I had to jump at the opportunity!

speaker: Subaki
text: Daughter...

speaker: Caeldori
text: I want to help! I really, really do! I'm tired of sitting home alone and waiting to be of some use. I'll never be as prefect as you are, Father. But I'd like to start trying to be! I have rigorously trained myself in martial arts, among other disciplines. I won't disappoint you.

speaker: Subaki
text: Caeldori, of course you won't. You seem like quite a wonder already! All right. Stay and fight alongside me. Don't get overconfident though. This is your first battle, after all!

speaker: Caeldori
text: Yes, of course. I'll do my best, Father!

speaker: Subaki
text: Almost perfect, Caeldori. I observed your every move. How can you be this good? It was your very first battle!

speaker: Caeldori
text: Thanks! But you must have seen that I'm still falling short of your standard. Perfect as you are, that is. Oh, what's this? You've torn your clothing, Father! I guess even paragons like you can have a bad day. I'll patch those right up. I'm sure I have a sewing needle among my other things.

speaker: Subaki
text: How...prepared of you.

speaker: Caeldori
text: Yes. I try. Oh! I also did a quick assessment of the injuries done to the locals. After visiting each and every one, I know that they're all going to be just fine. That us, if we can get them somewhere better for their recuperation. To that end, I've mobilized some of our troops to carry them out of here. I tried to think of what you'd do, basically. Did I catch everything?

speaker: Subaki
text: Yep, more or less.

speaker: Caeldori
text: Well, I also sent a scout ahead to make sure the way is safe. It is. And, I'm sure I wasn't as thorough as you, Father, but I also...

speaker: Subaki
text: ...Also?! Is she outdoing even me?!

speaker: Caeldori
text: Hey, Father! Hello?

speaker: Subaki
text: Hmm. At this rate, Caeldori will soon be more perfect than I am!

speaker: Caeldori
text: Father? Sorry if I'm boring you...

speaker: Subaki
text: Huh? No, of course not dear.

speaker: Caeldori
text: I must train harder. I know, I know... Someday I'll be as brilliant in battle as you are, Father. I swear I won’t let you down.

speaker: Subaki
text: I know you won't, Caeldori. Just don't push yourself too hard!

speaker: Subaki
text: Ugh! I'd better start pushing myself very, very, very hard. Or else my daughter is going to make me look like a day-one novice!

speaker: Selena
text: Found you! Hello there, Caeldori.

speaker: Caeldori
text: Goodness, Mother. You startled me. But don't you look impressive! As always. I don't know how you do it.

speaker: Selena
text: Hmm. Well, Caeldori, there's something I suppose I should tell you. When you were young, you looked so much like your father. But now... Time has its way with us.

speaker: Caeldori
text: What's that? How odd. Time has its—?

speaker: Selena
text: Um... How do I say this? Do you recall the tales I've told you about my mother?

speaker: Caeldori
text: Yes. Of course. You've told me much about Grandmother. She was as perfect a knight as has ever been seen. I've always felt that you and Grandmother were so alike!

speaker: Selena
text: ... Actually, it's YOU that's like my mother. You're her spitting image. By the gods, just look at you. Your face, your voice... The way you carry yourself...every move, every word you say...

speaker: Caeldori
text: Really? I'd love to think that I'm a little like such a great woman. I'll have to work even harder to honor her memory.

speaker: Selena
text: Well, you're doing fine. But... But... Just don't mess up!

speaker: Caeldori
text: Yes! I swear I'll do my very best for you, Mother!

speaker: Selena
text: Ha ha! All right, all right... I'm sorry. I didn't mean to overreact. And I promise never to go and die on you. Or abandon you.

speaker: Caeldori
text: Hmm? What, Mother? Are you being serious?

speaker: Selena
text: Um, well... Let's just forget I said anything, Daughter.
